## What is the problem?

### How many interaction directions do we need?

- Mixed data: continuous ${\bf x}_{con}$ + categorical ${\bf x}_{cat}$
- Interactions may be modeled:
  - continuous $\rightarrow$ categorical  
  - categorical $\rightarrow$ continuous  

**Claim**

> Once categorical dissimilarities account for the continuous variables,  
> the reverse interaction is unnecessary.

---

## Probabilistic view of dissimilarity

Any dissimilarity can be written as a negative log-likelihood:

$$
d({\bf x}_i,{\bf x}_{i'}) \;\propto\; -\log f({\bf x}_i \mid {\bf x}_{i'})
$$

For mixed data, we factor:

$$
f({\bf x}_{con},{\bf x}_{cat})
=
f({\bf x}_{con})\,f({\bf x}_{cat}\mid{\bf x}_{con})
$$

- continuous variables define geometry
- categorical variables are compared **conditionally**

This factorization already introduces **asymmetry**.

---

## Where interaction is needed

### Continuous component

Assume:

$$
{\bf x}_{con}\mid{\bf x}'_{con} \sim N({\bf x}'_{con},\mathbf S)
$$

$$
-\log f({\bf x}_{con}\mid{\bf x}'_{con})
=
\frac12
({\bf x}_{con}-{\bf x}'_{con})^\top
\mathbf S^{-1}
({\bf x}_{con}-{\bf x}'_{con})
$$

- captures all continuous structure
- no categorical correction required

---

## Final mixed dissimilarity

$$
d({\bf x}_i,{\bf x}_{i'})
=
\underbrace{
\frac12
({\bf x}_{i_{con}}-{\bf x}_{i'_{con}})^\top
\mathbf S^{-1}
({\bf x}_{i_{con}}-{\bf x}_{i'_{con}})
}_{\text{continuous geometry}}
-
\underbrace{
\log p({\bf x}_{i_{cat}}
\mid
{\bf x}_{i_{con}},{\bf x}_{i'_{con}},{\bf x}_{i'_{cat}})
}_{\text{all cross-type interaction}}
$$

**Key message**

> All continuous–categorical interaction is absorbed in one direction only.
